doc.title: IDP Education
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/IDP Education New FY26 guide rules out the bear-case. However upside capped on low visibilityIDP Education New FY26 guid_2025-08-29

passages.text: Reiterate Rating: NEUTRAL | PO: 6.40 AUD | Price: 5.89 AUD

IEL reported a largely in- line FY25, with adj EBIT of \(\) 119\mathrm{mn}\(\) - 50\% YoY; VA:\) \ \(119\mathrm{mn}\) . Student placement (SP) volumes declined \(29\%\) YoY & IELTS volumes declined \(19\%\) , both in- line with the company guidance. Stronger than forecast growth in placement fee \((+15\% \text{YoY})\) however led to a \(1 - 2\%\) beat vs. the Street's revenue forecast. The company reported \(17\%\) YoY decline in its contract assets & receivables, in- line with the \(16\%\) decline reported in SP revenues. This is an incremental positive as continued growth in contract assets (as \(0\%\) of SP revenues) in the last few halves was a key market concern.

The company provided a new FY26 guide, with adj EBIT forecast at \(\) 115- 125\mathrm{mn}\(. Per IEL, industry volumes are seen declining another\) 20 - 30\%\$ in FY26. However, expected outperformance vs. the industry volumes, \(10\%\) growth in avg placement fee and \(\) 25\mathrm{mn}\$ reduction in overhead costs would enable it to deliver flatish EBIT. While the new guide rules out the bear- case scenario of another double- digit decline in EBIT in FY26, we remain cautious on the quality of next year's earning s as the flatish EBIT guide is supported by \(\) 35- 45\mathrm{mn}\$ cash restructuring cost to be accounted as a one- off (i.e. below the operating line). We lift our FY26E EBIT by \(5\%\) and estimate it at \(\) 117\mathrm{mn}\$

We reiterate Neutral on IEL. While better than forecast cost reductions & strong growth in placement fee reduces the downside risk, visibility beyond a few quarters is low given restrictive & uncertain immigration policy settings. In our view, (1) the HSD tuition fee increases being done by many Aus/ UK universities is making overseas education less attractive for South Asian & Southeast Asian students and would hurt study abroad demand in the long- run, and (3) IEL would find it difficult to deliver share gains over the next 2- 3 years on higher competitive intensity in placements.

Our new PO stands at \(\) 6.40\(was\) \ \(4.25\) based on 50:50 blend of DCF and 23x CY26 P/E. Our target P/E multiple is lifted from 18x to 23x, driven by better than forecast cost reductions and growth in placement fee and is 1SD below IEL's historical avg (ex- COVID)
\\* For full definities of Qmethod measures, see page 8.
>> Employed by a non- US affiliate of BofAS and is not registered/qualified as a research analyst under the FINRA rules.

Valuation: PO of \(\) 6.40\(Our PO is lifted from\) \ \(4.25\) earlier to \(\) 6.40\$ now based on 50:50 blend of DCF and 23x CY26 P/E. Our target P/E multiple is lifted from 18x to 23x led by better than forecast cost reductions and placement fee growth and is 1SD below IEL's historical avg (ex- COVID). We think a discount to historical valuations is warranted given low visibility, heightened policy risks and slower growth profile in the future. Our DCF valuation is based on a FY26- 35E forecast of 7- 8% revenue CAGR and 20- 22% EBITDA margin (lifted from high- teens margin forecast earlier) given positive surprise on cost reductions. We utilize a (1) WACC of 8.3% and (2) 4.0% terminal growth rate.

The stock trades at 22- 23x fwd P/E, 1SD below its historical avg (ex COVID) Between 2016- 25, IEL has traded between - 20x fwd P/E and - 90x fwd P/E, with an avg of 33x (ex COVID years of 2020- 21). The stock is currently trading at low- 20s fwd P/E multiples, which is roughly 1SD deviation below avg
Source: Bloomberg, BofA Global Research
We lift our FY26E EBIT forecast by 5%. Visibility beyond a few quarters remain low

Source: Company, BofA Global Research
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Our PO of \(6.40 is based on a 50:50 blend of P/E based and DCF-based approach.

We apply a \(23xP / E\) multiple on our CY26E earnings to arrive at our P/E based valuation. Our target P/E multiple is 1SD below the historical avg (ex- COVID impacted 2020- 21), justified in our view, given weak growth outlook, significant policy risk and weaker cash flow conversion over the last few years (vs. history)

Our DCF- based valuation is based on (1) a FY26- 35E forecast of \(7 - 8\%\) revenue CAGR and \(20 - 22\%\) EBITDA margin, (2) \(8.3\%\) WACC and (3) \(4.0\%\) terminal growth rate. We assume a cost of equity of \(10.1\%\) , after- tax cost of debt of \(4.2\%\) and a target gearing of \(30\%\) .

Upside risks: (1) faster- than- expected increase in market share in student placements in existing source countries, (2) successful expansion into new source markets, (3) favourable changes to student immigration regulations, (4) faster than forecast growth in placement fee and (5) moat- enhancing M&As.

Downside risks: (1) adverse changes to student immigration rules in Australia/ Canada, (2) higher- than- expected decline in IELTS test volumes, (3) inability to reduce costs, (4) currency fluctuations and (5) competitive pressure from well- funded edtech start- ups in its placement business.
